author: A_Brickset_user
review: For those who may not remember this set clearly, let me detail it for you. This set comes with two of the most difficult to find shields ever released by the lego group, (the most difficult to find would have to be the blue lion shields with the hearts on it from set 1592: the town square) and they are a must have for any serious castle collectors. It also comes with a group of knights with no shield, and these are the two that gaurd the prince and the damsel. Shields were never released for these two knights, but the lego group did do a kind of homage to them in the form of stain glass windows that are being released with the 2000-2001 line of King Leo's castle. The prince was the only royalty ever released with any castle set until about 1994 when a king was finally created for us. But this is the only set he ever came with. I believe the the shields on this were some of the last to be released that required a decal to be placed on them to show the standard, although that may be changing now as Lego is really pushing the decal thing on us again.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: The BEST Minifig set EVER!
review:
If this isn't the best set to buy just for the figures, I don't know what is.  (I tried to buy a 2nd set just for the figures many times but got outbid each time).  The figures in this set are extremely good, including 2 knights with very special lifting visors. 

The gold-trimmed prince/king in the set is super rare especially as the gold trimmed suit is almost always faded away after 20+yrs. 

It's truly amazing the pieces you get in this set and how they're used, and what few people realise is this set has studded 1x1 cylinders with no hole on the top!  A truly unique enigma!

author: sijpe
title: A remnant from a more civilized age
review:
If one would compare this set with with the latest incarnations of the knights-theme, you can get an inkling of just how much the peoples mood and view on society has changed since the 1970's. In this set you won't find any forces of darkness, no ongoing struggle for survival and no monsters that pose a threat to society as medieval knights would know it.

What we see in this set is the highly romanticized view that people in the seventies held upon the era of chivalrous knights in a sporting competition. It's happy and colourful.

Makes you wonder what it would look like if this scene would be invaded by partypoopers such as vikings, trolls, skeleton-knights and the like. A little bit sick-minded, but probably good fun.

I like this set. It's a feelgood set, although I wish that the rare parts would be a little less rare. Especially the tree.

author: shenron
title: Simple, colorful and with high minifig density
review:
This very small set from early castle era is visually quite effective, hides a couple of interesting design ideas, and carries six minifigs

The princes' pavillion is really simple (the back wall could have had some variation) but it looks great particularly for the use of colors. The horses are effectively built with basic bricks, and sport a wonderfully simple barding designed with 1x1 bricks and 2x1 slopes.

The amount of rare or exclusive pieces makes this set a collector's little treasure. The red flags and the prince's shirt are possibly not available anywhere else. The shields and knights' and soldiers' shirts appeared only in the minifigures pack of the same year, and the knights' visors only in the same plus the yellow castle. Even the red girl's hair, shirt with pearl necklace and cypress tree are quite hard to find.

author: Gus_263
title: The first joust
review: The first of many castle jousts. In this, the horse is made with lego original pieces. This is colorful, and  the itens like flags and trees are great. The knights have helmets, that looks like with real knights. The weapons are too included. The minifigures are in the classic style, in the yellow color. Another thing too included in classic sets are the green plates. The colors of the itens in the horses are good, i rate this classic and first joust 5/5.

author: villicus
title: georgeous!
review: While i write this, this set stands in front of me. It was the perfect addition to the yellow castle. Its so bright and colourful, i loved the thrones design so much that i rebuild thrones like that and integrated it into the yellow castle. The minifigs are great, the patterns on breast and shield are wonderful. I also love those cypress trees. The red haired queen and the king were an important addition to the castle theme also - anybody must have been protected by all the other knights. I think, this is the most rarest castle set to get - but its worth every cent you spend on it. the jousting horses are great, just made from bricks but still impressive - thats what lego is about! i would give 10/5 if possible.

author: Ernst
title: The Knights' Joust, so far one of my finest sets.
review:
Overall 5 bricks : With some luck I managed to get this set and I consider myself lucky to be one of the 211 Brickset members who own it. It is a simple set but great, it shows the chivalry we admired being kids. It is simple but powerful thanks to the colors Lego used and its composition and completeness. Although I own a lot of sets and some big ones this is by far my favorite !!

Building 3 bricks : Building is not very difficult, a lot of big bars for the walls and plates and small bricks for the seats. The "hardest" part to built is the roof with the canopy but it is fun to do it.

Parts 5 bricks : Parts are not spectacular but chosen very well, especially the colors of the roof and canopy. The fact it gets 5 bricks is because of the completeness. The tree and the flags are superb, same goes for the 6 mini figures. Nothing special but all in place, a Prince without extravagant crown, a lovely Princess, 2 guards with axes and 2 two jousting Knights with only simple spears and shields. An extra remark here concerning the great visors of the Knights, very fragile but great.

Playability 3 bricks : Playability not more than 3 bricks, in my opinion this set is one to admire not to play with.

Value 5 bricks : Value is difficult, Bricklink gives an average of €92,50 which a good set is definitely worth. If you need it to complete the theme or just want it as collectors item you maybe are willing to pay more if it is in good shape. When writing this review none is offered on E-bay and 11 on Bricklink with prices varying from €72,00 going up to €210,00 which shows how hard is to find. I got it for a real steal and in a great condition including instructions as new so in general and for me personal 5 bricks here too.

author: SirSven7
title: Lego Steve's Review
review:
The Knights Tournament is my personal favourite set from this era, and that is due to one reason, the inclusion of the civilian figs, I remember when I was at school (at about the age of 10 or 12) my art teacher had this exact set glued upside down to the ceiling in his classroom (weird but true). Even in these very early sets, you can see that LEGO had a clear view to include civilians alongside the knights (after all what’s the point in being a good knight if you have no one to defend). 

This set is very colourful but it works well, the red and white roof, fits perfectly with the blue wall and yellow seats, everything is combined well, and the attention to detail is fantastic, the blue cups for the spectators, the tree and the barding for the horse’s are all completely new to the castle theme at the time.

 It should be noted that the female’s hair is an extremely rare piece (and even rarer due to its colour) and all the figs are unique to this set (excluding the service pack again), put simply if you own this set you have some very nice collector’s items. Again the alternative models for the set show that there was a lot of versatility in these old sets, something sadly lacking in the modern ones. 

If I had one flaw with the set it would be the fact that the printing on the figs (and flag) do not fit with the Castle set, it would have been nice to have the same faction owning the Castle and the Tournament, still that is a minor flaw in something that was very original (at the time).

 

If you like this review click on the link to find it and all reviews of the Castle sets

http://legosteveblog.blogspot.com/2011/06/classic-lego-castle-sets-1978-1983.html

author: iBudd
title: Beautiful! (and a minifig mystery)
review:
I absolutely love this set and remember getting it way back when. A couple of years back when I unearthed all my Lego I was thrilled to find I still had all the pieces (flags slightly bent, tree a bit crooked, minifigs faded) and now it's the jewel in my collection.

One curiosity though, one of the men-at-arms (cas230) has blue arms. And I dimly recall he may have had blue legs too (I have enough bi-colour legs from later castle sets for either to be the case but I have a lot of blues and not many blacks). Now I certainly didn't swap his arms out (I didn't know how and still don't) so he must have come like that. Anyone else ever see that?

author: mediAFOL
title: The splash of colour classic castle always needs
review:
Although I had the yellow Castle when I was young, the memories this set evoked as an adult seemed to be those of fascination and wanting. I don't think I had this set. I found a near-complete one to see if I liked it as much as the feelings it triggered.

The answer is yes. Firstly, tournaments and chivalric regalia are ideally suited to add beautiful colour accents to your medieval Lego world of grey, brown, beige, and green. Other tournament sets fulfil the same role, but there is something about the joyful colour in this one which immediately appeals.

The brick-built horses from the yellow Castle are not, perhaps, the most popular of builds. However, clad them in these wonderful brick-built caparisons, and they just make one smile. I'd take these magnificent creatures over their moulded equivalents any day.

Wholeheartedly recommended for any lover of classic castle.
